results.title: Shellshocked
results.creator_credit: Ramsey Films, Jane Ramsey and Stephen Ramsey
results.brief_description: Four very different Australian veterans of the Vietnam war, all permanently affected by shellshock, return to Vietnam as part of the process of healing the trauma they suffered. This documentary follows the veterans as they travel together, flashing back to their individual war stories which are illustrated with unique home video footage. The high moment of the film occurs when they meet with veterans from the other side: ex Viet Cong guerrillas who, just like the Australian vets, are suffering from post-traumatic stress. A film about redemption that provides some startling insights into the nature of war.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ramsey Films, Jane Ramsey and Stephen Ramsey

results.title: Shellfish gathering
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Frank L. Few
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Migratory habits of inland Aborigines who go walkabout to the coast to collect shellfish at certain times of the year, to augment their diet. The husband walks ahead and carries his fire sticks in his hair. His wife goes into the rock pools and quickly fills the string bag which hangs from her shoulder; cooks the fish in their shells in the hot ash; water is poured over the fire to cool the shellfish before they are removed and eaten.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Frank L. Few

results.title: Shell fishing
results.brief_description: Along the eastern coast of the united States, fishermen gather from the ocean and bays many different types of shellfish - oysters, crabs, clams, lobsters - using lines, traps and nets. Their catches are shipped fresh to many parts of the USA, with the aid of special packing and refrigeration; canned, they are exported all over the world. This film uses dialog recorded among the fishermen in various parts of the east coast of USA, thus emphasizing the rgionals differences in speech

results.title: Sheffield made
results.creator_credit: Ace Films, Frank Green and John S. Green
results.brief_description: How the steelmakers of Sheffield, with their traditions of skill and craftsmanship, are producing special steels. Shows how these same traditions, backed by research and modern equipment, are meeting the demands of designers and engineers, in the aviation industry and the construction of atomic power stations.

results.title: Sheet steel for a nation
results.brief_description: Describes the process of cold reduction of sheet steel as a stage in the production of galvanised, corrugated and other types of steel sheets. This process was first intoroduced in 1955 at Port Kembla in New South Wales. Shows how in the major operation, the steel strip rolls through rollers which exert tremendous pressure in reducing the steel to the required thickness.

results.title: Sheer genius
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Dept of Industry, Technology and Commerce and Tim Clark
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Quantum”.
Developed by Jim Haseloff and Wayne Gerlach of the CSIRO, “gene shears” technology offers a precise way of removing unwanted genes and viruses from plants and animals, a genetic scalpel which could revolutionise the breeding of plants, and lead to cures for cancer and AIDS. The history of this major new discovery is presented, stressing the priority now given to commercial development and protection of intellectual property through patents, against the free exchange of scientific ideas. Australian attitudes to research and development are also explored - Australian business has shown virtually no interest in developing and exploring this and other major new break-throughs in biotechnology.

results.title: Sheepdog
results.creator_credit: British Sccreen Service and John Alderson
results.brief_description: The work of a typical English dog in the wild Welsh mountains. A study of a shepherd’s workmate, his sheepdog; used to protect flocks from marauding foxes, to round up stragglers, and to rescue injured lambs or sick ewes.
